reviewText: Absolutely fantastic game with fun all around.  The dungeons are pretty entertaining, there is a nice selection of adventurers to use in them, and the dialogue in this game is mostly well translated, funny, and great.  Some tasks in this game can be repetitive, but the game makes up for that by later allowing you to avoid most of that repetition.  What's more is this game does actually have an interesting story for it's characters, which is always a good thing.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: A surprisingly addictive game!  This Japanese Indie (doujin) game has been translated very well and with loving detail.  The voices are still in Japanese (left unsubbed, but their vocals basically match the dialogue text anyway), but it doesn't take away from enjoying the game at all.  The item shop mechanics are simple but engaging, with challenges such as a change in trends and item value during certain times.  The dungeon crawler mechanics are also simple, with a top-down view of your character as you explore and defeat monsters.  There is also a way to fuse items in order to sell things that aren't regularly offered in stores.  Graphics aren't glamorous but acceptable, which is great for my laptop (not optimized for gaming)!\n\nThe game is, overall, fairly simple and not very complicated.  I think it's perfect for it's price and quality.  There is even a replay value to it for all the completionists out there.  That's more than I can say about some full-priced games in the market!

reviewText: I got this in a bundle recently and didn't really expect much from it. It's actually a really fun game that is done very well. The graphics aren't amazing, but they're definitely acceptable, and the game has a lot of humor and good design. It's kind of like a mix between Animal Crossing, Torchlight/Diablo, and that Lemonade Stand game you might have played in elementary school. Anyways, it's an interesting blend of genres to me, and the game has a lot of personality. I've found myself playing it for hours a day the last few days. I'm not sure I'd strongly recommend it at the suggested $20 price point, but if you can find it on sale, pick it up. Also, you might want to check out the demo. You might find yourself pulled in by its charm like I have.\n\nAlso, disregard the time played on here. I played this game mostly in offline mode, and I guess Steam doesn't calculate that playing time. I've played it for at least a dozen hours or so.

reviewText:
Ah... what to say about this.

Some good dialogue?  I mean... the game is about an item shop, and you'd hope that the designers would come up with some kind of mechanic to make that more interesting than it sounds?  Except they don't.  You're an item shop owner, and you sell things.  Initially that was enough for me, because the writing was pretty good and funny, and there was this sort of bare-bones dungeon-crawling side quest that helped spice things up.

The problem I had with the game is that it flat-out lies to you.  There is a tutorial at the beginning of the game that actually tells you what the sweet spot for sales gouging is, in terms of price percentage.  So you set out on your epic quest of consumerism only to find that eventually people dont have enough money to buy the items you need to meet your monthly financial goals.  This is because if you are not really generous in your pricing, your customers never level up" (something the game never tells you can occur).  If they never level up
date: they never earn a higher cash cap to spend in your store.  If they cant do that
recommended: they can't buy the items you need to sell in order to not lose.  I was about 95% of the way through the game when on the last month I came to the realization that victory was impossible (and sad to say the game does not have a tremendous amount of replayability).\n\nI was pretty irritated that the game instructed me in a method of play that was counter-productive given the hidden underlying system on which the game is built.  However

reviewText:
If you're not into the kind of art style you see in the trailer (cutesy, anime-esque) you're going to hate this game.

Which is a shame, because it's actually very good.  The entire premise is good, the dungeoning is frustrating, but once you get the hang of it (find an adventurer that clicks with your playstyle) it's actually very fun.  The item shop running" is honestly enough to carry this game on its own.

It's been out for a while so I'd pick it up on sale

reviewText: A friend asked me, HOW IS THIS GAME SO FUN?" I replied
date: "It is kind of impressive how fun it is being an NPC
recommended: isn't it?" And it is. You can't really summarize this game; it's got too many great things going for it
hoursPlayed: and attempts to do so generally result in disbelief that a game like that can be as entertaining as claimed.\n\nThe game's about running an item shop. Initially you have to pay off your debt but once that's done you enter "Endless Mode" and can enjoy being a merchant (and also running through dungeons to get loot!) to your heart's content. Don't be disheartened by failure; even if you fail to pay off your debt
voteText: you'll still get a second chance.\n\nGood luck getting 100% completion; the post-endgame content is ridiculously beefy
helpfulPercent: and filling out your item encyclopedia requires at least six or seven playthroughs. And even when you've got that sorted out
votesHelpful: you STILL have Endless Mode to challenge yourself with.\n\nAlso it's an indie title
votesTotal: if you like that sort of thing."

reviewText: Recettear is an interesting game. While it was originally released only in Japan, the translations into English help keep a level of humor that not only compliments the attitudes of the characters, but makes running an Item Shop" more interesting.\n\nDespite it's simplistic visual design
date: the game itself is very deep with a simple interface for managing business decisions such as buying and selling goods on top of haggling with customers.\n\nThis is one of those where if you looked at it and passed it as an obscure RPG that couldn't be worth your time

reviewText:
Good game with a flavor of Harvest Moon in it.  The game isnt deep in the combat sense but for what if offers is a great game.  I would recommend getting this when it is under $10.  The time sink in the game is easily 50+ hours because of the several new game modes that become available after you beat the game the first time.

The game works every day you have several turns to do stuff and those are devided in selling items at the shop, buying items around town and visting town, and dungeon crawling for items to sell or use on the your heroes you play as.  Every week you have to pay a debt so you do not get a game over.  After several weeks of paying the debt you win!  And then the game opens up lots of stuff for you to do and keep on farming and grinding.

PROS
-Great time sink to fix that Harvest Moon guilty pleasure
-Boss fights have mechanics and make the game not just a pure hac and slash
-One the game is beat you have lots of options to keep playing or just be satisfied with another game down
-For what is offered in the game is great

Negatives
-Not to crazy on the character development

reviewText:
Recettear: An Item Shop's Tale is cute and fun game. For me, this game is perfect collection of genres, combining a shop sim, a dungeon crawling action RPG, and visual novel style segments all into one game.

The basics of the plot is that you are Recette, a young girl who's adventurer father disappears and leave behind a crippling debt that threatens to take away your home and everything in it. So you along with Tear, the fairy loan officer responsible for you paying the debt back, open an item shop. From there on out you can go out into town to buy stock and meet people, or hire an adventurer to bring items you can sell back from dungeons.

The difficulty curve can be intense, with your payments going up exponentially. However, I would consider this to be a medium difficulty game. Neither the shop segments or the dungeons are too difficult, though they still can be hard and tricky.

There are 8 adventurers that you can unlock over the course of the game for the dungeon portions and each has a unique combat style and abilities from one another, so there is plenty of variety whether you want to change things up or find a style that suits you best. There are also 6 dungeons, each one harder that the first but providing better drops progressively.

The plot is presented in very cute visual novel style segments and is quite light and relaxed despite the goal to pay off an ever increasing debt. I find it fits the medium difficulty game play segments very well. To trigger most of the story segments requires you to leave the shop and waste a chunk of your time, but the characters are all unique, fun and quirky. It's also the only way to unlock some of your potential adventures, so it can be worth your time.

All in all, I love this game. It's not to difficult to pick up and has a lot of content available so you can keep playing for hours.

reviewText:
Ah... what to say about this.

Some good dialogue?  I mean... the game is about an item shop, and you'd hope that the designers would come up with some kind of mechanic to make that more interesting than it sounds?  Except they don't.  You're an item shop owner, and you sell things.  Initially that was enough for me, because the writing was pretty good and funny, and there was this sort of bare-bones dungeon-crawling side quest that helped spice things up.

The problem I had with the game is that it flat-out lies to you.  There is a tutorial at the beginning of the game that actually tells you what the sweet spot for sales gouging is, in terms of price percentage.  So you set out on your epic quest of consumerism only to find that eventually people dont have enough money to buy the items you need to meet your monthly financial goals.  This is because if you are not really generous in your pricing, your customers never level up" (something the game never tells you can occur).  If they never level up
date: they never earn a higher cash cap to spend in your store.  If they cant do that
recommended: they can't buy the items you need to sell in order to not lose.  I was about 95% of the way through the game when on the last month I came to the realization that victory was impossible (and sad to say the game does not have a tremendous amount of replayability).\n\nI was pretty irritated that the game instructed me in a method of play that was counter-productive given the hidden underlying system on which the game is built.  However

reviewText: Every time a Steam sale comes out, I purchase another copy of Recettear to give to another friend. It's impossible to resist sharing this wonderful game - it's a fun action RPG with colourful characters and memorable game mechanics. Where else can a gamer enjoy the thrill of a fantasy adventure, the cuteness of moe characters and the joy of cutthroat mercantilism, all at the same time? In the words of the heroine: Capitalism, ho!
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Most unexpected fun you can ever have out of a shop-sim. Recettear is about management, of both time and resources, and it's good at that. It also has an overview-grid action RPG-mechanic that isn't as interesting and at times gets pretty tedious, but it's still head and shoulders above average.

The real draw here is the store. Not only is the shopkeeping gameplay plenty addictive for its beautiful aesthetics and atmosphere, but it's also very understanding about difficulty. Every time you happen to fail your quest to save your store from bankruptcy, you get to keep your experience points from the previous go and the next attempt will be a whole lot easier afterwards. You simply cannot fail if you just keep failing long enough, so experts will complete the game in one go, while beginners will slowly learn by getting stronger from failure. A very balanced system for all kinds.

Plenty of replayability if you know what's good for you. Capitalism, ho!

reviewText:
It's an interesting take on the usual RPG where, instead of adventuring, you're the shop owner.  The game is about a girl name Recette that is living all by herself ever since her father ran away.  She originally created the shop in order to shoulder the large debt that her father had built up over the years.  Tear, the other character the game gets its name from, is a debt collector that helps manage the store so that you can maximize your profits.

While this seems like just a boring management game from my description, it actually does have moments where you can go out and fight monsters.  Recette can hire heroes to help her collect items to sell in her store.  The game turns into an action RPG for those moments with gameplay that's not dissimilar to the top-down entries in the Legend of Zelda franchise.

This game has colorful characters that populate the city.  While most of them are kind of cliche, it fits with the game's atmosphere.  This is supposed to be an action RPG from the eyes of Recette, the girl who runs the item store.

reviewText:
Recettear.. I wasn't sure what to expect when I saw this game, but I bought it because it was on sale and seemed moderatly interesting.. How wrong I was. Monderatly? This game is amazing! It's such a refershing change on typical RPG's!

Owning your own store is pretty interesting, you have to keep earning an increased amount every week or you're screwed. Seems boring right? But somehow bartering prices for both purchases and sales with your customers is rather exciting (Except when a certain little girl tries shopping). As you progress in levels, new features are added like taking orders for item.

For item gathering itself, you have the option to buy items from the Market and Mechants Guild, aswell as items customers are trying to sell. However the best and obviously most fun option, is hiring an adventurer and going out to dungeons to slay monsters, find chests and collecting items to sell in your shop. The combat system is EXTREMELY basic, you have your movement keys, an attack button and a special attack button.. Thats it, but somehow the combat still feels great and rewarding. While you start out with a single adventurer, you eventually lock others of a different class, each with their own moves and differences. Whats cooler is these aren't just random characters you fight with, each one of them has their own personality. You see them at the town center, pub, church or even shopping inside your store.

And these adventurers aren't the only ones with personalitys! There are quite a few characters in the game, and while not all of them have names, you can see a general personality and gain familiarity with them. The random man will typically buy goods for this much, while the little girl won't do it for more than this. You can see aspects of their daily lives in town, and with the familiarity you can actually get feelings towards people shopping, good or bad! You'll know this person likes to haggle, these people are cheap or these people will accept higher prices.

This is a great twist, and while the idea of it might not sound great, it is. It brings a fresh and great idea with excellent exacution, with an art style that never goes bad! Even $20 is a great price for a game!
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Sure, the game starts off as your typical Japanese cutesy thing. But soon enough, you realise things.
For one, customers are not your friends. You won't win any prizes for selling at cost price. You go higher... a hundred and five... hundred and ten... hundred and fifteen... High, but not high enough to make them suspicious.You'll learn how they act, what they'll spend, and go in for the kill.
Adventurers will be your tools. Cavediving may seem like an extra, but it's the only way of finding some of the most profitable treasures. You don't wanna buy from a wholesale seller or such - after all, that means less profit. You'll give them some equipment, maybe some food, and then hope they come back alive.
Perhaps they will. After all, you play them. But if they die, you can only take a few things with you back up. Maybe you'll sell something to them, later, when they come browsing. At just under 150% of it's base price.
Underneath that cute exterior is a game about making money.

reviewText:
Capitalism, ho!

You're a cute little air-headed sweets-loving girl with a deadbeat dad, ginormous amounts of debt, and a Kuudere fairy that's trying to help you get out of it, instead of just making you homeless or eating your soul.

You've got rivals from other shops to compete with (though that doesn't play much in the game itself from my experience), and you've got a bunch of adventurers you can go dungeon crawling with. One of which is a thief that starts out pretty much as a meanie-face, and another that's a worthless and penniless adventurer wanna-be that'll ask for your stuff for around 75% of the base price (meaning you lose money when you sell to him unless you dungeon crawl with him to get items, and he'll use the items he gets from you) when he shops at your store.

Everything is cute to disguise the horribly realistic scenario of children being forced to pay their parents debts for the rest of their life, unless they're good with CAPITALISM, HO!

It's got an amusing dungeon system, though people complain about the hit boxes being bad (I haven't noticed it) or having to always attack in a linear manner (you don't, quite a number of the attacks hit everything in a half circle in front of you) they aren't real problems unless you're very, very rigid and perfectionist. It's tedious, yes, but what dungeon crawling game isn't? I have yet to run into one that doesn't become a tediously boring thing after a dozen or so floors, and this one has dialogue, plot, and new characters interspersed throughout it to keep things at least a little interesting.

If you don't like ditzy characters, cutesy dialogue, and a bunch of anime-esque plots then this probably isn't the game for you, but if you've been watching anime for a while and like to sink some time into dungeon crawling without it being the only thing to do in a game, then this game might just be for you.

Some people complain about having to do things over and over again" and I can only say one thing: too bad
date: so sad. Darn near every game is like that
recommended: and always has been. The only reason it's "different" now is that you perceive it differently because it's gotten boring."

reviewText:
Capitalism, ho!

We've all played adventure games and RPGs, and we've all gone to shops in those games and bought items we wanted and needed, even sold off a few items we found and didn't need, right? Well, ever wonder what the game would be like from the merchant's point of view? Me neither, but this game lets you experience it anyway.

You play as Recette, a young child who supposedly just lost her father and now must basically turn part of her own home into a shop to pay off her father's debt with the aid of the fairy Tear.

The game is a lot more entertaining than it sounds, and can be pretty funny at times. The child's voice, though, after a while can become annoying (as does some of the shoppers...) but you grow accustomed to it after a while.

It's a cute and fun game and I do recommend it. And don't worry, even if your math skills are a bit lacking, this game won't be hard on you whn it comes to pricing items. So buy cheap, sell high, and most of all have fun! Capitalism, ho!!!

The game is not only about buying and selling though as through out the gme you have the constant debt you must repay which quickly increases making this a quick yet relaxed game. This game is what you make of it and what you put in is ultimatly what comes out.

reviewText: A lovely doujin game, part strategy, part tycoon, part dungeon crawler. You play as Recette Lemongrass, a clueless young girl who is given 4 weeks to pay off a loan her father took and disappeared with. You take over his shop where you can buy and sell various items to earn money. You can buy and resell items from the marketplace, or from people or you can go and do dungeons to get items without having to pay for them.  The idea of the game is to earn a profit while keeping your customers happy so that they will return for repeat business. The game gradually introduces gameplay mechanics until you realize that there is a fairly deep game hiding behind the cute exterior presentation.\n\nDon't be put off by the Japanese style, the Anime look or the fact that it's made in Flash. This is the reason we play games... to discover new and wonderful experiences that can be had through this medium. I thought it was worth full price, but it's definitely worth getting in a sale.

reviewText:
Most unexpected fun you can ever have out of a shop-sim. Recettear is about management, of both time and resources, and it's good at that. It also has an overview-grid action RPG-mechanic that isn't as interesting and at times gets pretty tedious, but it's still head and shoulders above average.

The real draw here is the store. Not only is the shopkeeping gameplay plenty addictive for its beautiful aesthetics and atmosphere, but it's also very understanding about difficulty. Every time you happen to fail your quest to save your store from bankruptcy, you get to keep your experience points from the previous go and the next attempt will be a whole lot easier afterwards. You simply cannot fail if you just keep failing long enough, so experts will complete the game in one go, while beginners will slowly learn by getting stronger from failure. A very balanced system for all kinds.

Plenty of replayability if you know what's good for you. Capitalism, ho!

reviewText: I got this in a bundle recently and didn't really expect much from it. It's actually a really fun game that is done very well. The graphics aren't amazing, but they're definitely acceptable, and the game has a lot of humor and good design. It's kind of like a mix between Animal Crossing, Torchlight/Diablo, and that Lemonade Stand game you might have played in elementary school. Anyways, it's an interesting blend of genres to me, and the game has a lot of personality. I've found myself playing it for hours a day the last few days. I'm not sure I'd strongly recommend it at the suggested $20 price point, but if you can find it on sale, pick it up. Also, you might want to check out the demo. You might find yourself pulled in by its charm like I have.\n\nAlso, disregard the time played on here. I played this game mostly in offline mode, and I guess Steam doesn't calculate that playing time. I've played it for at least a dozen hours or so.

reviewText:
It's such a casual, yet deep dungeon runner with loveable characters and easy-to-play controls. Although it is lacking in story materials, the main fun just comes from the running of your own item store. Every hirable adventurer has their own unique playstyle ranging from warrior, thief, archer, lancer, mage. The adventurers also have their quirks and characteristics that make you want to play as them. If you can't pay your debt in time, you start again from day one, but your adventurers still have their items and stats (but you have to find them again,) and the stores retain the items that they sold you from your previous progression through the game.
Some bosses and enemies come back from Chantelise, but it's not really a bad thing as the game is not very hard until you get to the later dungeons (then it gets pretty hardcore.)

reviewText:
Recettear is a perfect storm of cuteness and capitalism, all wrapped up nicely in Japanese paper.  I know a few people with this game, and wel all play it differently.  I tend to focus solely on my storefront, one person I know spends all his time in dungeons, and yet another has something of a 60/40 mix between the two, leaning towards dungeon play.

One of the things that makes Recettear such a great game is that all of these playstyles are completely viable.  The item shop really is yours, and you can do whatever you want with it, provided you make the proper payments on time.  Want to make a dark cabal, where ancient artifacts of mystical Lovecraftian horrors are traded behind closed doors?  Done.  Want to make a homemaker's paradise, with clothes and food and tools as far as the eye can see?  Easy enough to put together.  Or maybe you'd rather outfit adventurers to go expeditioning with you, offering them low prices on advanced gear?  Great idea.

Recettear manages to give you more empowerment than most store simulation games, and that's only half of what it is.  Its dungeon-crawling aspect is, to me, a little contrived, and not as well executed as, say, Torchlight, but it certainly gets the job done, and if loot gives you joy, you'll probably find the later dungeons particularly pleasing anyway.

And let's not gloss over the art and writing, both of which are some of the cutest available, anywhere, ever.  This is the game that coined the word Yepperoni" which is probably the most important English word I know.  If you're not into cute stuff

reviewText:
Recettear - if I had to sum it up in a couple of words, I would describe it as a concept that should fail, but doesn't. The gameplay is repetitive, the dungeon crawling requires excessive amounts of grinding to gather materials, and the light-novel/anime style is probably a turn off to some.

In practice though, Recettear is an unexpected hit, and a real hidden gem. Recette herself is adorable and everything she does just makes players want to love her more. The concept is fresh and unusual: run your very own item shop, pay off the loan-shark fairy! Play smart, watch for special deals, buy low and sell high to try to maximize your profit! Balance between the general approval of your customers and your profit margins to maximize revenue!

Not only is the concept of running one's own item shop interesting on its own right, but the game can be unexpectedly challenging. Many players fail to pay off the debt and have to use the game's mulligan" system to complete it (or mulligan by save-scumming) because they got too greedy seeing a deadline approaching
date: or because they failed to account for a potential drop in an item's value.\n\nEarlier I mentioned that the dungeoneering is pretty bad
recommended: and that's true to an extent: there aren't many dungeons

column18: are a huge part of what gives Recettear its charm.\n\nSure

reviewText:
There's already a slew of other reviews telling you this is a good game. They probably either focus a lot or not enough about the sum of all parts. I'm going to only explain why I personally think this game turns from good into great.

Dungeon crawling is considered awful and/or boring for most people I know. They like shooters or some sports games. A few actually like RPGs. And Recettear is definitely a good RPG with a fair amount of simplistic dungeon crawling. It's also interesting how its simplicity aids the game's concept, because if you're anything like me you'll actually like more the character's shop management than going into dungeons to sell the crap out of what a monster unwittingly thought was fun to be lugging around for no reason.

In other words, I think the whole shop management deal is what makes Recettear a good game. If I were to judge it solely on the dungeon crawler aspect I'd tell you that I've played many considerably better dungeon crawlers. Heck, I'd even tell you that Rogue and a great part of it's infinite spawn of clones and wannabes is a better game on dungeon crawling alone. But the shop management, from what goods you'll display on that particular day, the kind of display furniture you're using, and even the little feeling of having sold the junk that some monster considered valuable enough to carry for astronomical values to the masses of curious customers... is only 14.99 away from you.

Let me sweeten the deal here. Carpe Fulgur, the publisher, is one of those that normally has its games featured on discounts on Steam. It's not uncommon to drop around 60% of the price from time to time. And you can't say that the cute-as-kittens-and-fun-as-(games I suppose?) protagonist and its struggles don't capture your heart to the point where you will want to help her get the funds for the next loan she NEEDS to pay, and then see the story evolve gradually with the other characters she gets involved with.

Also, you get to see the witty translation of whatever the original game had in its original language of (I assume) Japanese into Capitalism
hoursPlayed: among other instant classics. There's plenty of humour to read in the dialogues
voteText: and sometimes you'll think that you're also paying for a comic book with all of the grins

reviewText:
Recettear.. I wasn't sure what to expect when I saw this game, but I bought it because it was on sale and seemed moderatly interesting.. How wrong I was. Monderatly? This game is amazing! It's such a refershing change on typical RPG's!

Owning your own store is pretty interesting, you have to keep earning an increased amount every week or you're screwed. Seems boring right? But somehow bartering prices for both purchases and sales with your customers is rather exciting (Except when a certain little girl tries shopping). As you progress in levels, new features are added like taking orders for item.

For item gathering itself, you have the option to buy items from the Market and Mechants Guild, aswell as items customers are trying to sell. However the best and obviously most fun option, is hiring an adventurer and going out to dungeons to slay monsters, find chests and collecting items to sell in your shop. The combat system is EXTREMELY basic, you have your movement keys, an attack button and a special attack button.. Thats it, but somehow the combat still feels great and rewarding. While you start out with a single adventurer, you eventually lock others of a different class, each with their own moves and differences. Whats cooler is these aren't just random characters you fight with, each one of them has their own personality. You see them at the town center, pub, church or even shopping inside your store.

And these adventurers aren't the only ones with personalitys! There are quite a few characters in the game, and while not all of them have names, you can see a general personality and gain familiarity with them. The random man will typically buy goods for this much, while the little girl won't do it for more than this. You can see aspects of their daily lives in town, and with the familiarity you can actually get feelings towards people shopping, good or bad! You'll know this person likes to haggle, these people are cheap or these people will accept higher prices.

This is a great twist, and while the idea of it might not sound great, it is. It brings a fresh and great idea with excellent exacution, with an art style that never goes bad! Even $20 is a great price for a game!
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Sure, the game starts off as your typical Japanese cutesy thing. But soon enough, you realise things.
For one, customers are not your friends. You won't win any prizes for selling at cost price. You go higher... a hundred and five... hundred and ten... hundred and fifteen... High, but not high enough to make them suspicious.You'll learn how they act, what they'll spend, and go in for the kill.
Adventurers will be your tools. Cavediving may seem like an extra, but it's the only way of finding some of the most profitable treasures. You don't wanna buy from a wholesale seller or such - after all, that means less profit. You'll give them some equipment, maybe some food, and then hope they come back alive.
Perhaps they will. After all, you play them. But if they die, you can only take a few things with you back up. Maybe you'll sell something to them, later, when they come browsing. At just under 150% of it's base price.
Underneath that cute exterior is a game about making money.

reviewText:
Capitalism, ho!

You're a cute little air-headed sweets-loving girl with a deadbeat dad, ginormous amounts of debt, and a Kuudere fairy that's trying to help you get out of it, instead of just making you homeless or eating your soul.

You've got rivals from other shops to compete with (though that doesn't play much in the game itself from my experience), and you've got a bunch of adventurers you can go dungeon crawling with. One of which is a thief that starts out pretty much as a meanie-face, and another that's a worthless and penniless adventurer wanna-be that'll ask for your stuff for around 75% of the base price (meaning you lose money when you sell to him unless you dungeon crawl with him to get items, and he'll use the items he gets from you) when he shops at your store.

Everything is cute to disguise the horribly realistic scenario of children being forced to pay their parents debts for the rest of their life, unless they're good with CAPITALISM, HO!

It's got an amusing dungeon system, though people complain about the hit boxes being bad (I haven't noticed it) or having to always attack in a linear manner (you don't, quite a number of the attacks hit everything in a half circle in front of you) they aren't real problems unless you're very, very rigid and perfectionist. It's tedious, yes, but what dungeon crawling game isn't? I have yet to run into one that doesn't become a tediously boring thing after a dozen or so floors, and this one has dialogue, plot, and new characters interspersed throughout it to keep things at least a little interesting.

If you don't like ditzy characters, cutesy dialogue, and a bunch of anime-esque plots then this probably isn't the game for you, but if you've been watching anime for a while and like to sink some time into dungeon crawling without it being the only thing to do in a game, then this game might just be for you.

Some people complain about having to do things over and over again" and I can only say one thing: too bad
date: so sad. Darn near every game is like that
recommended: and always has been. The only reason it's "different" now is that you perceive it differently because it's gotten boring."

reviewText:
How to haggle like a pro.

Usually, the hero of a video game is the representation of what society views as 'strong, courageous and tough'. This is why male heroes make up such a collectively large proporition of protagonists in video games and all mediums of entertainment; books, movies, lolcat memes (not the norm) are all forms of entertainment that attribute widely to the popular - and I emphasize popular- social stigma of society.

Examples are here:
Fifty Shades of Grey: Super hot stuff
White men can't jump: Self explanatory
Locat memes: Desire to anthropomorphize ourselves into kittens.

Now let's focus on Recettear again.
Let's say 'hypothetically' that Recettear is 'different' from the norm. Instead of a strong male lead, you now have a female lead who starts off relatively inept (Not an opinion against females, just what the character starts off as). Her only benefits being that she doesn't need to eat, or atleast from what we can see, and that she can follow a schedule better than any student or adult in the known world. Also, she's an anime girl: the truest and strongest form of feminist pro propagandanism.

So what gives?
How are we supposed to connect with this game if there isn't anything remarkably 'interesting' to connect to?

Well, that's the essential difference in video games; it doesn't need to because video games aren't all words or film.

Here's why:

Recettear is absolutely blossoming in charm from its art style (animesque) to the gameplay (finances 101). It's a mix mash of japanese tropes/culture,dungeon crawling and finances. Though, I wouldn't go so far as call it an RPG because it's remarkably hard to connect with the main character, but it serves well in its main drive of gameplay; the flesh of the gameplay is the retrieving and selling of products with a hint of dungeonesque elements, specifically you need to get sellable materials from the dungeon to sell. And boy, you want to sell, sell and sell because debts in game come in fast. In fact, never has procrastination on debt lead to such dire consequences where a little a girl gets evicted from her home to the doghouse, though if that's your thing...

However, in the end, the frantic nature of gameplay makes each decision a calculated decision to maximize profits from retrieving and selling. Thus, you will want to haggle everyone despite your best conciousness;
a little old lady, how nice! Sell the bagel at 500% mark up. It's a deal she can't refuse, literally! (Starving old lady)

It's a game that will teach you how exploitative you can be and you know what? That's the best form of video game.

Simple game of buy low / sell high, with a little dungeon crawling for entertainment. I enjoyed it, but low replayability once you clear it.

reviewText:
This game is... strange, in a good way.

It's all about running an item shop and crawling through dungeons for items to sell, or ingrediants to make better items. The start is a bit slow and the combat could be better, but it picks up quickly as the days go by. The story of the game is all about you being the daughter of an infamous adventurer who left a massive debt in his name, and you're the only one who can clear it. With the help of the business fairy, Tear, you'll work through a month to pay off the debt... or you'll have to sell your house!

Good things about this game:

+Good music
+Unique theme
+Various items to find and a unique system for equipping your adventurer with items
+Various characters to run through the dungeon with
+Dialog is interesting, if not a little childish due to the age of the main character
+Beating the game, or failing to do so, will allow you to 'restart' with all your items and 'Merchent Level' in tact. This lets you get up in money much faster than you would do so at the start, but you don't keep any of your money or your progress through events.
+Decent end-game content that makes it worth while to try and get what you need
+Haggling is a pretty neat concept, though it takes practice to get it down right.
+Characters are interesting and have their own unique style, in dungeons and just in general.

Bad things about this game:

-Combat could definitely be better, with hit-scan and certain abilities. Some characters are just notably better than others.
-Events are picky. You have to know when you need to go to places in town to get certain chat boxes, which can affect how you get items, characters, or unlock a new location. This causes you to lose a 'block' of time, too, and not all events do anything.
-One girl will come in and sell you something and refuse to buy anything. She'll always refuse to sell at 100% of the item's price, too. 200% is the minimum for her, and there's no way to get rid of her after she appears. You can refuse to buy it, but this messes up your combo and makes you level up slower.
-Getting the 'true card' for characters takes too long. True cards let you use your adventurer without having to find them in the story, which can be helpful for clearing dungeons again. But getting the True Card requires you to beat the game and use that adventurer the most. (More than any other adventurer, that is, for that month.)  To get another one, you have to play the game /again/ and use a different adventurer.
-There's little 'stats' to the game that you can see, at least in my experience. There /are/ stats, but you can't really see them except when your adventurer is buying an item that is better than what they have. You can't even see how much people like you to adjust your prices.

Despite the lengthy part of the 'bad stuff', I really just offered more explanation as to what and why it was bad. This game is still amazing to play, especially if you like dungeon crawlers. The 'bad' things are just my opinion, anyways, and the good things weren't as descriptive because I don't want to spoil anything!

reviewText:
This game is adorable, clever, full of fun characters, and addictive. There are two major modes of playing: haggling with people and running your item shop, and adventuring in the game's procedurally-generated dungeons.

The Item Shop  is the game's primary mode of play (given that it's part of the title). You control your inventory, the look and feel of your shop, and spend a lot of time haggling about prices with your customers. The tutorials are more than good enough, and the cute characterization makes them worth doing. Playing as an RPG item shop's owner is a creative and refreshing idea (though not totally unheard-of. See Taloon's chapter in Dragon Quest/Warrior IV)

The Adventuring mode is a bit simplistic, but doesn't overstay it's welcome. The easiest way to describe it is a cross between one of the 2D Zelda titles (A Link to the Past comes to mind) and The Secret of Mana. It is responsive and does a good job of breaking up the buying/selling action of the Item Shop mode.

Near the end of my playthrough I did find the buying and selling getting a little repetitive as I'd memorized the preferences of every customer. I was able to successfully finish the game before I got really bored of it, though, and had an enjoyable experience, especiallly for the money.

I never finished all the adventuring dungeons, so there is probably more to the story I never saw. I might go back and do that at some point.

Buy it if you like RPGs or Tycoon" style games. It's cheaper than a fast food meal
date: and will entertain you for at least 10 hours."

reviewText: Recettear is fun, charming, and an original take on the JRPG genre. It combines simulation elements with the RPG genre. In the game, you run an item shop in an attempt to pay off Recette's father's debt with the help of the fairy Tear, who also works for the company collecting the debt. In the game you will meet many adventurers, whom you can hire to go with you into dungeons to look for loot to sell in your shop. Micro-management is a big factor in this game, as you need to make sure to have enough money at the end of the week to pay off your debt. Each day is set into four segments, and each time you open the store or leave the shop costs a segment, while going into a dungeon will cost three. If you don't have enough money when your debt is due, then you will need to start at the beginning but with character progress getting carried over. Overall, this is a great game that JRPG fans should definitely not pass up.

reviewText:
The Oliver Review

The Story

The story is a main part of this game. It allows the player to fully immerse themselves in the events of the game. Recettear does a phenomenal job at this task. I found the story incredibly enjoyable. I felt the emotions alongside the characters. The principle may seem basic, but if you really connect to the characters, this will be an experience you will treasure for al of your gaming life.

The Gameplay

The gameplay is amazing on its own. The active task of setting up a shop and selling your items is an invigorating feeling. Starting from the cheaper items, and steadily working your way up to the more expensive assortment of goods. It gives you a feeling of accomplishment that you have a hard time getting out of most other games. With the increasing difficulty of the game, it has both a challenging and a relaxed atmosphere. The other aspect is the Dungeons. You send out a hero you get from interacting with them either around town, or in your shop. In these dungeons, the more expensive variety of loot lies deep in them. The gameplay in these areas is a bit faster paced, but overall the game tends to be patient and relaxed.

The Personality

The game is very relaxed. It does take it slow throughout the whole experience. The games failure  mechanic is that you start from the beginning, only you still have your levels and items. The game has a feeling of accomplishment with everything in it. Whether it be gaining a level, or selling that expensive item. This game makes you work for it, but still guides you along the path enough so you don't feel lost.

The Rating

In The Oliver Rating system, this game has the Oliver Rating of

4.7/5
This game has my recommendation to  Play and Replay

reviewText:
The game is fun and offers some stratagy based money management as well as requiring a bit of luck.
In standard new game there are only 2 dungeons, one is basically a tutorial dungeon with not a lot to offer the other is a 3 part dungeon with a 4th area allowing you to fight just the bosses over and over again.

Early in the game dungeon crawling is a must to gain pix, however later on, for me it was after just the 2nd week, it no longer seems really helpful.

Often times townspeople will come in selling an item and then before the time segment is even over will buy it right back. One of the best ways to make money is buying for 30% and reselling for 130%.

One of the best items to stock up I found was weapons, in later weeks they get boosts in value and can be sold for as much as 300% base. For me the last 3 days all weapons were increased in value, not sure if it was luck or game mechanics, but in the last 3 days alone I amassed over 300k pix.

The game does have NG+ as well as a survival mode, but for the most part there doesn't really seem to be a whole lot of replay value after you intitally beat it.

I bought it on sale for 9.99, not 100% I got my moneys worth, but it was definitely a fun game. I have a total of around 7 hours in the game including offline time, and that's about the amount of time it took me to beat it with having to start over once. I'd recommend buying it, but definitely on sale for 9.99 or less simply because of how short the game is, and how little replay value it offers in my opinion.

reviewText: A lovely doujin game, part strategy, part tycoon, part dungeon crawler. You play as Recette Lemongrass, a clueless young girl who is given 4 weeks to pay off a loan her father took and disappeared with. You take over his shop where you can buy and sell various items to earn money. You can buy and resell items from the marketplace, or from people or you can go and do dungeons to get items without having to pay for them.  The idea of the game is to earn a profit while keeping your customers happy so that they will return for repeat business. The game gradually introduces gameplay mechanics until you realize that there is a fairly deep game hiding behind the cute exterior presentation.\n\nDon't be put off by the Japanese style, the Anime look or the fact that it's made in Flash. This is the reason we play games... to discover new and wonderful experiences that can be had through this medium. I thought it was worth full price, but it's definitely worth getting in a sale.

reviewText:
Recettear: An Item Shop's Tale is cute and fun game. For me, this game is perfect collection of genres, combining a shop sim, a dungeon crawling action RPG, and visual novel style segments all into one game.

The basics of the plot is that you are Recette, a young girl who's adventurer father disappears and leave behind a crippling debt that threatens to take away your home and everything in it. So you along with Tear, the fairy loan officer responsible for you paying the debt back, open an item shop. From there on out you can go out into town to buy stock and meet people, or hire an adventurer to bring items you can sell back from dungeons.

The difficulty curve can be intense, with your payments going up exponentially. However, I would consider this to be a medium difficulty game. Neither the shop segments or the dungeons are too difficult, though they still can be hard and tricky.

There are 8 adventurers that you can unlock over the course of the game for the dungeon portions and each has a unique combat style and abilities from one another, so there is plenty of variety whether you want to change things up or find a style that suits you best. There are also 6 dungeons, each one harder that the first but providing better drops progressively.

The plot is presented in very cute visual novel style segments and is quite light and relaxed despite the goal to pay off an ever increasing debt. I find it fits the medium difficulty game play segments very well. To trigger most of the story segments requires you to leave the shop and waste a chunk of your time, but the characters are all unique, fun and quirky. It's also the only way to unlock some of your potential adventures, so it can be worth your time.

All in all, I love this game. It's not to difficult to pick up and has a lot of content available so you can keep playing for hours.

reviewText: Recettear is very much a delightful game that will keep you entertained for roughly 10 hours depending on how you play (for one play through). The game revolves around running an item shop, and the challenges that brings. It also has adventure opportunities where you can play in some very basic Legend of Zelda-like game play (better example would be Neutopia on the TurboGraphics 16) from the original NES days, although with better graphics, in order to acquire rare and cool items for sale. There is a ton of content it seems for this game, but most of it you will likely not use during the main course of the game. The reason being that taking advantage of such usually requires risk, and since you have to meet monetary goals within a certain amount of time in the main story, you may choose to go a safer route. Nevertheless, this game offers quite the charming gameplay despite it being repetative at times. I highly recommend this game if you can manage to get it for $10 or less. If not, then it really depends on how many hours of gameplay you expect at minimum to get per dollar you spend.

reviewText: A true gem. It's quirky, cute, and all around fun. The concept is simple: stock your item store to earn money and pay off a loan. However, it quickly becomes much more in depth. You can buy items when the prices drop and sell them for a profit later, or hire an adventurer and head off to the dungeons in search of treasure! If you've ever been a fan of games like Rune Factory, Harvest Moon, Summon Nights or other hand held games like those, you'll probably love this game. There's something about it that becomes truly addictive, trying to stock the store, get cool new items all while trying to earn (and keep) enough to pay off those weekly loan payments! Even more, it has some of the most interesting and entertaining characters, who you really begin to learn more about and see dynamics between them all, in and out of your shop. The game itself has personality, as off the wall phrases like Capitalism

reviewText:
Recettear is a perfect storm of cuteness and capitalism, all wrapped up nicely in Japanese paper.  I know a few people with this game, and wel all play it differently.  I tend to focus solely on my storefront, one person I know spends all his time in dungeons, and yet another has something of a 60/40 mix between the two, leaning towards dungeon play.

One of the things that makes Recettear such a great game is that all of these playstyles are completely viable.  The item shop really is yours, and you can do whatever you want with it, provided you make the proper payments on time.  Want to make a dark cabal, where ancient artifacts of mystical Lovecraftian horrors are traded behind closed doors?  Done.  Want to make a homemaker's paradise, with clothes and food and tools as far as the eye can see?  Easy enough to put together.  Or maybe you'd rather outfit adventurers to go expeditioning with you, offering them low prices on advanced gear?  Great idea.

Recettear manages to give you more empowerment than most store simulation games, and that's only half of what it is.  Its dungeon-crawling aspect is, to me, a little contrived, and not as well executed as, say, Torchlight, but it certainly gets the job done, and if loot gives you joy, you'll probably find the later dungeons particularly pleasing anyway.

And let's not gloss over the art and writing, both of which are some of the cutest available, anywhere, ever.  This is the game that coined the word Yepperoni" which is probably the most important English word I know.  If you're not into cute stuff
recommended: or you think it's lame or contrived

reviewText: Different is the name of the game with this quirky little RPG/Economy game, Recttear.  Somewhat difficult to explain, Recttear must be experienced to be fully understood. You own a store and hire characters to go down into the dungeon to fetch you treasure to sell. The game is split into those two basic parts; selling the goods at the store, and hunting in the darkened dungeon to find lost treasures. This two part approach worked for me as I found myself playing to get my store awesome and my heroes to be ultra-awesome. Recttear is a bit dated and the story is basically devoid, but the game is very fun and highly addictive. You’ll find yourself mumbling just one more level often as you tack on the hours in this enjoyable game.

reviewText:
This was one of the first games I bought on Steam, and I stand by my decision to buy it after all these years. It is a game that puts an unique spin on the RPG item shop staple, by forcing you to take a crash course in profit-making, stock management, and haggling. Hell, calling this Baby's First Management wouldn't be far off if the game wasn't so unforgivable on those that don't cater to their clients (Then again, it's not like starting from the beginning was a brutal punishment when you keep your things, but still).

Fans of dungeon crawling, on the other hand, won't be dissapointed as the adventuring feels very well done, and, more importantly, each of your mercenary pals not only plays differently, they really feel differently, right down to movement and battle mechanics. This might not seem strange in a game tailored around the theme, but in a game focused on store management this comes as a pleasant surprise.

Also, the ammount of content in this game is absurd: The story itself isn't exactly long, and as you struggle against the loan deadlines you may come to loathe the moment when no other shoppers try to buy something it may feel short, but trying to get all the true adventurer cards, trying to fill out your in-game glossary, and really, just trying to get the true end itself will feel like you're playing one of those JRPGs that have no end in sight after a hundred hours.

If the economics, the dungeon crawling and the collecting still haven't sold you into it, maybe you'll give it a shot for the sheer hillarity and referencing in this game. And remember, the demo is there to help you make a more informed decision than what the shopkeeper tells you, so give it a shot before buying. Finally, it's not like you can't haggle the price down, if you decide to buy it eventually, after all, that's what steam sales are for. Capitalism, ho!

reviewText:
Very fun!

I feel this needs to be elaborated more, as I have finally cleared the main game and off to the post-game content. It took me a very long while to finish this as I had failed the last payment on my first time, and after finding out it sets you back on day 2, I got demotivated (that's not entirely true though, apparently you keep your end-game items when you reset so you get that extra boost on your next try, but I did not know that back then), but after giving it another go I was able to finish it with money to spare.
This game... Is AMAZING... this is something that costs like 10 bucks, I bought for something like 3 and I've already accumulated 44 hours and I intend to play even more for the post-game. The graphics are cute, the voice acting is great though it is not fully voiced, the dungeons are simple but interesting, though it is my complaint that they are too lengthy, depending on the character you choose it will take about 2 hours or something to clear unless you are rushing it (but then you miss out on phat lewt, who would want to miss out on phat lewt?). I guess if there was an end-game tier item that automatically revealed the map when you took it could cut out on some of that time as you'd only move to the treasure chests? I did not check if there actually is an item like that, though.
I'd say the dungeons make up about 3/4 of the time you'd spend on the game (mainly due to how lengthy they are), and for the last fourth you'll be selling stuff in the shop, though it may be a bit awkward at start, you eventually get used to it. There are many numbers and percentages involved that you can only find out through experimentation or visiting the wiki, I'd say it's worth skimming over them or else you'll screw yourself over on your first run. Also, I'd say thank god that the text for when you buy or sell has a different color, because the speech before it sometimes sound a bit ambiguous.
I really hope I can find other gems like this one in the future. Thank you based Comiket, thank you based EGS, and thank you based Carpe Fulgur!

Capitalism, ho!

reviewText:
TLDR version: Doesn't exactly reinvent the wheel and can get repetitive but for any fans of JRPGs or dungeon crawlers, this little gem does more than enough to justify the modest asking price (Pssst this game goes on sale often)

Story and Characters: You play as Recette, a cheerful naive and only somewhat annoying little girl whos carefree life gets shattered when her father disappears and she's left to pay his debts to a fairy named Tear. Your goal is to open the store her father left in order to pay off weekly payments to Tear or lose your home. It's not exactly on the level of the Count of Monte Cristo but for a cutesy game like this it's all the motivation you'll need.

The characters are pretty simple anime cliche, but most are charming in their own right. Tear makes a great straight man to Recette's bubble-headed obliviousness. Charme the thief is a likeable rogue and kind of like a big sister to our lead. That being said a number of characters are very one note and that note is typically rude and nasty for no particular reason". Still
date: you have the option to skip any dialog and if your anything like me your finger will fly to that escape key any time you see that irritating rich girl.\n\nGraphics: The visuals are decent
recommended: they do their job expressing the world but they aren't very inspired. Customizing your store is the most visually impressive part of the game. Expect to see a lot of brown and gray dungeons copy pasted almost to the point of frustration. Closeups during dialog convey a great sense of personality but the actual models only look OK. Animation is nice and smooth and the frame rate is pleasingly consistent throughout which is all that really matters in a budget title like this.\n\nAudio: Voice acting is all in Japanese and it's cute
hoursPlayed: if a bit unnecessary with dialog being mostly text. The music isn't really worth noting. It's mostly cute and bouncy MIDI tunes that loop over and over. By far the most awful thing about the game is the ear-bleeding harmonica track that plays when walking around your store. It didn't take long for me to mute the music
voteText:
and you likely will too.

Gameplay: This dungeon crawling ARPG has just enough twists to the classic formula to really make it addictive. Your time will be split between selling items in your store and running down to the dungeon hoping to find loot to sell at said store. It's easy to assume the selling part would be the weakest but it's amazing how nail-biting selling stuff can be when your next payment is due tomorrow and your still 5000 short. Do you jack up your prices and risk a customer walking out on you? Will anybody buy that really expensive item you absolutely need to sell to make your payment? How much is too much for a chocolate bar? This game manages to make such a mundane idea quite exciting.

The dungeon crawling is also quite fun if a little basic. You start with just one swordsman to dungeon dive with but you later unlock a quick thief
helpfulPercent: a glass cannon mage
votesHelpful: etc. They all have different items to equip
votesTotal: different abilites
votesFunny: and different special attacks so there's enough variety to keep it fresh.  Enemies are generic looking but each one has different attacks and movement patterns
commentsCount: such as knights being able to protect themselves with shields or the winged eyeballs shooting lasers at you. The only real issue I have with the controls is the momentum characters gain while moving seems a bit too much. I found myself walking straight into enemies I meant to avoid or having a hard time wheeling myself around to hit their weak spots before they moved.\n\nWhat really stands out is the way RPG conventions are subverted. This might be the only RPG I've ever played where my characters level didn't matter to me. After all
column16: the game measures your progression almost completely with money
column17: so while filling your merchant EXP bar grants new perks to make the money pile up
column18: the combat EXP isn't nearly as important. Sure tougher dungeons usually have better loot but the only reason I was happy I leveled was for the HP refill so I didn't have to use any of the healing items I found. I didn't really know or care what level my hero was as long as I could carry out a huge bag of loot.\n\nAll in all
column19: Recettear: An Item Shop's Tale is a fun
column20: cute and simple ARPG well worth your time and money. It's not for everyone and it's not exactly the kind of game that will leave you glued to the edge of your seat but it has novel gameplay and lots of charm sure to appeal to the RPG crowd looking for something different. And hey
column21: if you enjoy story mode and you can play challenge mode and fulfill your fantasy of fighting your ever-growing debt until the massive payments force you into bankruptcy! Sorry

reviewText:
How can I recommend this game enough... it is so incredibly good.  It is cute, it is engaging, it has a great story and is localized to a T every time; running the store is fun, adventuring on each character is fun, and the personal challenge mode availability is fun.  (i.e. just for fun, play through and make yourself finish every dungeon on your first run-through without stopping or failing, although you will experience loot anguish.)  The alternate modes that are available are also fun to begin with.

This is - alternately run an item shop and go adventuring, and as a result, do various collecting of all the story, all the things, all the money, all the characters, and various vanquishing of all the monsters, traps, and dungeons.
Take the above, add the Cute descriptor, add the Fun descriptor, and add a whole bunch of interesting internal mechanics and you get my lots of hours.

Anyway, this is one of my favorite games, so this has been my feeble attempt at a review.

reviewText:
How can I recommend this game enough... it is so incredibly good.  It is cute, it is engaging, it has a great story and is localized to a T every time; running the store is fun, adventuring on each character is fun, and the personal challenge mode availability is fun.  (i.e. just for fun, play through and make yourself finish every dungeon on your first run-through without stopping or failing, although you will experience loot anguish.)  The alternate modes that are available are also fun to begin with.

This is - alternately run an item shop and go adventuring, and as a result, do various collecting of all the story, all the things, all the money, all the characters, and various vanquishing of all the monsters, traps, and dungeons.
Take the above, add the Cute descriptor, add the Fun descriptor, and add a whole bunch of interesting internal mechanics and you get my lots of hours.

Anyway, this is one of my favorite games, so this has been my feeble attempt at a review.

reviewText: On the surface, it's just a cutesy indie Japanese item shop simulator, but what surprised me was the amount of depth and polish that went into the game's RPG and dungeon-crawling aspects.  The gameplay is very open-ended -- you're free to spend all your time playing with the economic side of things, or (if you're like me) you can focus on leveling up your various adventurers and slashing/blowing up/punching/shooting all sorts of baddies and neglect your shop entirely.  The story is pretty cheesy, but the interactions between characters are always entertaining.

reviewText:
The only knock on this game is that the difficulty progresses as a misleadingly steep pace.

That said, the game does handle that well enough inside of itself- you can take what you learned (and earned)- into future attempts.

The characters are cute, the gameplay, while a little rough around the edges is perfectly playable and most importantly fun.  You can't ignore the shop aspect, which I think some might find as a negative, but that's the sell of the game, not the dungeons- you play as the shop keep, not the dungeon crawler, after all.

All in all, this might be my favorite game on Steam.  It does everything it sets out to do well, which is something that we can't objectively say about most games.

reviewText:
Recettear....an adorable little RPG that doesn't take itself too seriously, because it doesn't need to. While it may be short, with a story mode easily completed in 4-6 hours, there is a surprising amount of depth for those who seek it.
For completionists, the main goal is to complete the item encyclopedia, which seems simple enough...however, even after a playthrough of the story mode, you may only be left with <25% completion, especially if you never went through the dungeon. You may have also missed many cutscenes, and missed several potential unlocks. Luckily, the game provides an endless mode for you to clean up any loose ends, and start going towards that 100%!

Pros
-cute art style

-Dialogue is well-written, with many subtle jokes and references you may not get your first way through.

-Recette and Tear are a very likeable pair, and they all have unique reactions to other characters.

-Surprising amount of depth, with dungeoneering, crafting, and a small meta game of equipping your adventurers with the best gear.

-Simple, yet effective game mechanics

-Soundtrack is nice

-Offers a fair amount of post-story content, including an endless mode (continue playing without having to worry about debts), New Game+ (With new content. Start over from day 1 with levels and items intact and repay the debt again) and survival mode (where you have to keep paying back the debt, and see how long you can last).

Cons
-Art style, especially in dungeons, can be inconsistent. Some mobs are 3d, while your player characters are always 2d sprites.

-Game will either be extremely easy to get through, or RNG will doom you into a situation where you are failing to pay off your debts

-You don't need to do any dungeon'ing or crafting to complete story mode

-Time management can be a bit troublesome, since going through dungeons requires you to give up almost an entire day in your schedule.

-Small frustrating issues, such as being unable to see outstanding orders without speaking to Tear in the shop. (If you leave to go purchase wares, you lose a share of time, and you can only double check what items you need by returning and wasting another share.)

-Dungeon combat is pretty simple, and can be very grindy


Neutral

-Game lies to you, and fails to tell you about important game mechanics. (do NOT sell for 130% base price)

-Why are you selling knives to children...?

-New Game+ is incredibly easy. The amount you must pay never increases.



Overall I actually really like Recettear. It's cute, enjoyable, and can certainly be stressful sometimes. There are a few issues, such as major game mechanics being more risk than reward during the story mode. Still, I would recommend this game not only because it provides for a surprisingly absent genre of game (running an RPG store), but it provides it in such a way that is very appealing and cheerful.

reviewText:
Fun, fun, and fun.

This has a nice little small business Sim attached to it is a old school dungeon crawler system. I enjoyed everything

gameplay 9/10
mix between a sim of running your shop and a dungeon crawler

soundtrack 7/10
sound effects can become irritating over time, but not immediently so. But both the music and sound effects are enjoyable and fit well to the game.

Story 8/10
Without too high expectations this is very enjoyable. A girl is left to fend for herself after a fairy shows up saying your missing deadbeat dad has left all his debt to you. The story progresses as you pay off this debt and find new heros to fight for you as you enter dungeons looking for sweet loot.

Animation 9/10
I honestly don't know what else I could want animation wise. It's all cute. Not epic cut scenes or anything, but visual novel and cute dungeon craw animation.

Controls */*
I prefer the use of a controller for the dungeon part of the game, but works fine with keyboard and mouse. It's well done for either way, but i think just comes down to personal preference.

This game is truely one of my favorite purchases on steam.

reviewText: The tutorials are hand-holding, the challenge level is punishing, and some of the characters are a little annoying (if adorable), but /Recettear/ is absolutely worth a shot, especially if you don't think you'll like it. The game looks like a JRPG, but it doesn't have the hand-holding character of FF13, or even of FF6; it's more like a roguelike with a graphics budget than it is like anything else. (Be warned, you can't win the game with shopkeeping alone. Nor with dungeon crawling alone -- I think you need to go for item creation as soon as the game starts hinting that it might be a good idea...)

reviewText:
Okay. If you're curious to find out what kind of game this is, It is a game about capitalism, and running your own little items shop as the title of the game implies. It has a decent combat system, a likeable protagonist, and very nice guidelines to learn how to play most effectively. Although the music does get VERY aggravating at times in my opinion. All in all, I have had an absolute blast with this game.
Pros: 1. Good shop customization
2. Decent characters and storyline
3. Rewarding combat system, addicting gameplay that keeps you occupied for hours.
Cons: 1. Wonky movement with the arrow keys when you're fighting in a dungeon. (It's tolerable)
2. Repetitive music and voices. (I had to turn those off within the first hour of gameplay)
3. THE BLONDE ♥♥♥♥♥ AND HER FAIRY THAT TRIES TO BUY ♥♥♥♥ FOR 3% OVER THE BASE PRICE, AND KIDS WHO COME INTO YOUR SHOP WITH THEIR LUNCH MONEY AND PICK OUT A 7,000 PIX SWORD AND WON'T PAY UP!

Other than that. Great game. I rate 9/10 :)

reviewText: As someone who vaguely enjoys a good japanese-style rpg every now and then, I can safely say that Recettear: AIST is a stunningly well done game. The music is semi-retro SNES / early PS1 (in the best way possible i mean), the dungenons are fun and satisfying, and overall the game has a great personality. The japanese-only sfx dialog is a little irritating at times but it can be forgiven, especially with the great presentation and fun factor.\n\nTL;DR Highly recommended, very unique RPG that puts a nice twist on a basic dungeon crawler.

reviewText:
On your bog standard RPG, you are an adventurer on your way to save the world, fight armies, or even just picking berries. But in this game, the roles are reversed and you're the owner of an item shop that sells items and weapons to adventurers.
This game is very fun to play, and I have put about 17 hours into it already, with the intention to put in more.
I would reccomend this game to RPG fans, but I can see why some may not like Recettear. The enemies are not that diverse and the RPG elements are rather shallow. However, that is not where the true appeal of this game comes from. No, that comes from the buying and selling of items. It is awesome to buy say, a cake during a food shortage, giving you an excuse to charge extortionate prices (such as 300% of the original price) and make a but load of money.
Character wise this game delivers well enough, giving you the doofy but likeable Recette, the stern but kind Tear, and many more characters (though I will admit to not remembering most of their names, just very prominant parts of their personality).
In the end, I would recommend this game...as long as you get it in a sale.

Running this item shop is a lot more fun and rewarding than grinding for experience on Final Fantasy XIII: Corridors and Cutscenes. reviewText:
Recettear is quite possibly my favorite game on Steam.

Concept: Your father ran away and left you in massive debt.  The collection agency sends out a fairy to get someone to pay up and that just happens to be you.  What are you going to do?  Open up an item shop in the middle of RPG-ville.

Yeah, that's right.  Other suckers are out there killing for loot but you're chilling back in town playing the markets and raking in the dosh.  Buy your products from the guild or from the street merchants and turn right around to sell it to the townsfolk and the adventuring crowds.  Expand your store, learn the folks, and fleece them for every red cent they've ever made.

Not exciting enough for you?  Want some action or maybe some rare items to sell?  Press those adventurers into servitude and hit up the dungeons for fresh wares.  Press on, gather everything, and keep it for yourself while the so-called heroes risk their lives for your profits.

Capitalism, ho.
voteText: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game startled me. It just didn't seem like it'd be that much fun... I thought it'd be maybe kind of relaxing to run a shop, and that'd be the end of it.

I was sorely mistaken.

This game is just plain, downright fun. Frankly, I'm not entirely sure what's so enjoyable about it. The leveling system, the shop system, the integration of dungeon crawling and the item shop, the ability to switch back and forth according to one's mood - it just allows for a very relaxing experience, with just the right amount of emotional pressure, to make you want to really do your best.

I've had this game for a couple of years now, and I keep coming back to it, every now and again. It's just... well, fun.

reviewText:
2 parts business simulator, 1 part dungeon crawler - if that idea appeals to you I cannot recommend this game hard enough. You take on the role of the Item Shop owner in an RPG based world and supply the adventurers and regular townies with much needed supplies of every nature.
But it's not just about stocking your shop - because of course no one's going to pay sticker price for your ♥♥♥♥; damn adventurers and their haggling. Warning: You may want to drown the Little Girl for never having any money ever.
The smart store owner stock piles items when they're cheap and sells them when they go up in value, and if there are ingredients you just can't buy from your suppliers, well then it's time to hire a sell-sword (whom you equip and level up yourself) and kill some monsters in a nearby dungeon, complete with multiple randomized levels and some fun bossfights.
Adorable art style, great gameplay, so simple and yet so much fun, easy to sink a ton of hours into. Happy gaming.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Never before have I played a game that I can describe as beautiful in such an eclectic sense. The town looks absolutely stunning on the PC. The story is rich and provoking, keeping you guessing and revising your theories as you play. The final scenes will haunt you, driving you (or at least many) to the forums to absorb and discuss thoughts on the plot possibilities. The music is captivating and enthralling, with all of its drama. With extra orchestral stabs to accent details such as how you finish an enemy, the experience really feels complete and integrated. The gameplay is familiar for fans of the previous Carpe Fulgur games, with new innovations to spice things up. Zipping around the town and dealing out devastating blows is both effective and immensely satisfying. No game is perfect, as no form of entertainment/art is immune to subjectivity but this game comes so close that it deserves a 10/10 for being worth every single coin spent on it.

Good heaven's this is a great game! I beat it in 2 sittings because my 1st sitting went until 4AM and I realized that was no time to be awake! reviewText:
This game is surprisingly fun and challenging,
I really enjoyed the idea of being the shopkeeper in the game as opposed to the hero,
It was a really neat perspective to take for a game in the RPG sense.

There are a couple of aspects to the game, business management, where you need to set prices, run your shop, buy more inventory to sell and pay attention to the markets.
On top of that there is a action rpg element to it as well, where you take control of an adventurer and the 'loot' you find can be sold in store to customers the next day.

reviewText: In this RPG-spoof-dungeon crawler, you get to play the part of one of the many shopkeepers you may remember passing by in any JRPG.  Somehow they managed to not only make a hilarious game, but also one with memorable characters, great shop-based gameplay, and a challenging dungeon crawler.  This is a must-play for any fan of RPGs who wants something different.

reviewText: Recettear brings two main gameplay mechanics - shop ownership and adventuring - and brings them together in a smooth, well crafted game. Both the shop management and adventuring work well as separate mechanics and tie together in the way in which you sell items to the adventurers. reviewText:
Whenever I play any RPG like Skyrim, Fable, Fallout, MMOs, whatever, there is one thing I always, ALWAYS end up doing: Nitpicking my way through all the dungeons, grabbing all the most valuable items I can carry, bring them back to shops, and sell them for as much as possible. The money I earn doing this usually turn into a dragons hoard, since I never actually spend any of it back, I just try to collect all the stuff.

And along comes Recettear, a kinda roguelike RPG where doing exactly this is the core gameplay, wrapped in a painfully adorable cutesy wrapping, and carrying along with it a passably interesting story on top.

My inner Jew could hardly be happier, Capitalism Ho!

reviewText:
The sort of game you didn't know you needed. Who knew running the item shop could be more interesting than being the JRPG protagonist? Well-balanced game elements, in a fairly addicting little package. Kuwai japanese voices, but that could probably be assumed from the screenshots posted in the store. Not especially difficult, if you keep your eye on the market, but lots of aftergame content and challenge modes to give it replayability. Pretty standard action-rpg outside the shop, but a polished generic RPG is what you'd expect from a game that's really trying to hijack rather than be one. Slightly oddball charicterization keeps you in the right frame of mind. A bit niche, but nails it.

Capitalism, ho!

(Frankly, that line is Show me your moves!!!"-level quotable.)"
