reviewText:
Recettear: An Item Shop's Tale surprises and delights on a level that I didn't expect from such a small game. There are many facets to this game that are on the surface missed, but appreciated after many hours playing the game.

The story is rather simple, you are left with the care of a shop and are required to pay back a debt that your father left you with, so capitalism and careful planning are your only means of digging yourself out of this debt. At first the requirements seem staggering, as each week you progress you're required to pay back more than the last, but the game is forgiving and if you miss a payment you'll restart in a better spot than when you first started your game.

This game truly shines if you enjoy item management (as I do, clearly), as well as RPG elements that aren't extraordinarily deep but yet very enjoyable. The shop management experience found in this game, as well as the bartering that you're required to do to excel, is something that I had never experienced before and found it delightful.

Sound for this game is so-so, and could be better but certainly doesn't detract from the overall appeal of the game. The graphics work well for what the game is looking to accomplish. Unfortunately, the supported resolutions require me to typically run the game in windowed mode (I have multiple monitors that are connected to my desktop, and it's a hassle to go full screen with Recettear). This is a minor annoyance, but certainly something that won't affect all players.

Finally, the controls work well for the game, and I typically play with a connected controller. The support for the peripheral has proven to be one of the largest draws for the game, as I can kick back in my chair and play for a couple of hours with relative ease. I use a wired Xbox 360 controller, but I'm sure that other similar configurations from either the 360 or One will function just as well.

Overall, I recommend Recettear for anyone looking for a new and unique experience. This game has a lot of potential, and while I have played the sequel a little, I find myself continuing to enjoy the original. Be forewarned, however, that this game is not for everyone. If you find item management in other RPGs tedious and a piece that you'd rather avoid, do not buy this game. It really won't prove to be to your liking.

reviewText: Recettear is a charming little game, with a novel approach (for those who don't know, in this game you own the item shop and you're selling to adventurers), and if you can get over the kawaiiness and the fact that it's not a multi-million dollar big fat budget production, you'll discover that this game is fun, challenging, and quite refreshing. Big companies have a lot to learn from this game, and it's definitely worth picking up, especially when it goes on sale again (as it's bound to do).\n

reviewText:
For the first 15 minutes, Recettear is a slog with it's sacchrine sweet animu story, music and characters.  The talking (and by talking, I mean reading) carries on forever as the stern midrif bearing librarian looking fairy lectures you on the ins and outs of being a child laborer/shop owner.  Then you finally get done with the lectures, you open your shop, you maybe go explore a dungeon for some items, and the next thing you now an hour has passed.

It's a steep price entry, all that slow reading to kick things off, but once you get to the meat of Recettear, it's kind of charming.  The dungeon exploring (which you technically odn't even have to do) is not too shabby, set in real time instead of your typical turn based combat that japanese RPGs' tend to use.  Once you load up on items, you had back to your shop, put them up for sale, make a little money.

The haggling system seems kind of pointless, but you know...whateveer.  It's still enjoyable.  Not something I'd power through in marathon sessions, but if you can get past the tooth ache that the oh-so-cute setup gives you, it's an allright game.

reviewText: The best game I have ever played in twenty years of computer gaming, bar none (and I have played a LOT of games). Eight years on I can still recall how profoundly that game gripped me, and I am not an overly emotional person. You will care about the characters, you will be moved, you will make choices that tell you more about yourself. It sounds trite, I know, but it really is that good. If only someone would make more of these...insightful, intelligent, devastatingly creative. Fallout is the only RPG to come close. A word of warning: You MUST read all the text, explore all the dialogue options, if you are to gain the most from the game. A decent intelligence and wisdom score is recommended.....although so is a decent score in everything else....the game does the best job of making usually superflous statistics genuinely useful that I have ever seen. Still very much worth playing.

reviewText:
Not quite a RPG but still close enough and more importantly: great fun! What if instead of being the hero, you were the item shopkeeper, selling to and buying from adventurers?

There's quite a bit more to it too, brought about progressively: negotiating prices, taking orders, managing stock, dungeoning with adventurers to get loot, changing your shop's atmosphere to attract different customers, finding new adventurers and learning about them and their backstories... It's a very cute game although prepare to see the dark side of capitalism if you fail to make your loan repayments in time ;)

The demo is quite comprehensive and I heartily recommend giving it a try to see if you'd like the game.

reviewText:
Recettear has a great amount of gameplay for its worth. Story is fairly unbelievable. A little girls father who has disappeared leaves his daughter with a huge crippling debt. She's only 10 (I am guessing?) how is she suppose to repay his debt? Why the fairy Tear tells her to make a store so she can pay it back. The lil loli Recette gets help and turns her house into a store. While the story was fairly unbelievable and lacking there isn't much to do but if you do the RPG dungeon part more stories unfold and builds up more character for Recette and Tear and the Adventurers.

Characters in the game have a huge impact. Everyone is unique and different and the events that happen make them rememberable enough. The more you unlock the more events that will happen interacting with all the characters all together. It gives incentive to do the dungeon part of the game to unlock more of these characters with their corky bits and pieces.

There are two different types of gameplay here. Running the Store and the Dungeon Crawling. Running your store was great but a challenge. Everyone has a different budget and you have to learn that by personality and age. The little girl is well in fact a little girl so she doesn't have much money. Louie is poor but the more adventuring you do with him the more money he gets and if you sell to him cheap he starts to get a bigger and better budget. It's so crazy and complex that each character in the game has specific things and goals and all this other crap that it's difficult to explain! Combat was simplistic but each Adventurer has their pros and cons and a different playstyle required. Not much to talk about here but it kinda reminded me of Final Fantasy without the turn base thing.

Long story short, scamming off little girls or spent your life living in a cardboard box.

Whats your choice?

reviewText:
You've got a loan to pay, but you're just a girl who's Dad has gone off adventuring... No worries, as an item shop, you'll be able to sell stuff to repay your loan! One problem though... Isn't that really boring? And you can't just sell apples 24/7... (Well, you COULD).
When you're bored, or you want super rare items, what other way to pass the time than going into a dungeon! Slay monsters with dedicated Adventurers, outsmart traps and find the really expensive treasure!

You decide the price the customer should pay, but if it's too high, they'll leave in a bad mood; too low and you're not making any profit (but you'll win a place in your customer's heart).

Was the main story too easy? How about an endless mode where your loan just increases every week? How long will you be able to hold out?

In my opinion, it's definitely worth the price.

reviewText: At first glance, Recettear may seem like some generic Japanese game, and the reason for this is that it doesn't do much to present itself as anything else; however, the game is one of the more unique titles I've seen among the massive amount of choices in the Steam library.\nRecettear is a mix between a Commerce game, an Action RPG, and a Visual Novel.  If you don't like one of the three, don't take part in it, that's what makes the game so interesting.  If you simply want to experience the semi-complex sales and marketting system, by all means.  If you just want to kill everything and earn money that way, that's fine too.  Maybe you want to just delve into alchemy and fusion; by all means.  Or maybe you just want to engage yourself with the deceptively unique characters that the game has to offer, you can do that (though it'd be rather difficult on its own).\nThis is the type of game that will definitely take a bite out of your life, and whether you are into Japanese games or not is irrelevant.  Recettear is a game that is what you make it, and let's you play the way you want to play, and it is certainly worth a play.

reviewText:
In this game, you play a young girl who, for story reasons, has to manage a shop in a town.

You can buy the items you're going to sell, or you can hire an adventurer and follow them into a dungeon (you control the adventurer), where you can earn items to sell. This will take more time than just buying items, but can be a lot more lucrative. CAN be.

The game is basically divided into those two sections, but you could play the entire game without ever entering a dungeon, if you wanted.

While the graphics and the game itself is quite cutesy, the gameplay is quite interesting. Figuring out how much you can charge each shopping personality type (e.g. Old Man, Young Girl etc.) can be a little annoying, but there's a pretty good Wiki for the game if you roll that way.

The worst thing is probably the ridiculously-long and unskippable intro.

The best thing is probably the way that Recette (the main character) and Tear (her fae overseer/friend) interact. And also when Recette says CAPITALISM
date: HO!". That was just so cute.\n\nThis game was everything I expected
recommended: and SO MUCH MORE!\n\nIf this interests you
hoursPlayed: download the demo - you can use your demo savegame in the full version when you buy it!"

reviewText: Sure, you can go into dungeons, beat up some monsters and steal all their loot, but it's much more interesting to play the item shop owner who's supplying those brave adventurers.\n\nMechanically it's an OK game.  The dungeon crawling portion is serviceable, but pretty much any dungeon crawler would be better.  The economics/shop aspect is interesting, and it claims depth through the customization options, but I had no trouble finishing the game largely ignoring anything beyond the basics.  It's a good way to kill some time without thinking to hard, but if you're looking for a complex game you'll find better options out there.

reviewText:
This is a simulation of a dystopian society where child exploitation happen.

Your main character is a loli who apparently forced to enter a dark dungeon spanning from 5 floor down to 100 Floor or more to pay for your parents debt by a haughty debt collector fairy.

The debt are hidden from you so you do not know the amount of the debt nor you know how many of the debt is real or a scam.

Every week the fairy will force you to pay a sum of money or you will be kicked out of your only home left by your parents, and do not hope for government assistance because there is none.

As a loli, you need make money and now as a player you will guide the loli how to make money effectively via capitalism.

You will need to cheat and lie to customer to sell your item so you can have a roof.

10/10 recommended for social studies

reviewText: At first glance, Recettear may seem like some generic Japanese game, and the reason for this is that it doesn't do much to present itself as anything else; however, the game is one of the more unique titles I've seen among the massive amount of choices in the Steam library.\nRecettear is a mix between a Commerce game, an Action RPG, and a Visual Novel.  If you don't like one of the three, don't take part in it, that's what makes the game so interesting.  If you simply want to experience the semi-complex sales and marketting system, by all means.  If you just want to kill everything and earn money that way, that's fine too.  Maybe you want to just delve into alchemy and fusion; by all means.  Or maybe you just want to engage yourself with the deceptively unique characters that the game has to offer, you can do that (though it'd be rather difficult on its own).\nThis is the type of game that will definitely take a bite out of your life, and whether you are into Japanese games or not is irrelevant.  Recettear is a game that is what you make it, and let's you play the way you want to play, and it is certainly worth a play.

voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
An addicting wee game with some issues.

It's a very fun game with likeable characters, a fun idea and an interesting theme that seems weirdly addictive for how simple it is.

There are a few gripes that may bother you and make it less fun and you should be well aware of these.

The main gripe is that this game is very much a victim of the RNG a lot of the time. You might get 10 customers in your shop suddenly and think This is great!" ... then you notice 5 of them are little girls who generally won't give you much profit whatsoever. You'll be nearing a payment dead line for your loan and suddenly your biggest selling product will become very common and will reduce in half for the price or you'll want to sell and instead you'll suddenly be pestered by dozens of people just wanting to sell you stuff instead or want to place orders for AFTER your loan date.

It's one of those games where if you get to day 30 and suddenly realise you only have like 50K
date: you pretty much aren't going to win the game. There is no real way to pull a rabbit out of the hat and you might as well just restart the game which is quite frustrating when you put 10 hours into the game and realise that you're pretty much screwed.\n\nThe dungeon fighting is fun but a bit repetitive after awhile
recommended: especially since there is honestly a very small selection of loot to pick from and you will soon get annoyed at how restrictive the game is based on the 'time units'.\n\nYou get 4 time units a day and lose these with certain tasks. Opening your store to sell is 1 unit
hoursPlayed:
going to town to meet characters (which I enjoy but it seems a punishment since meeting a friend takes away a lot of your selling day which makes the game feel punishing if you try and enjoy their story) but going to the dungeons cost 2 time units. Sometimes you'll go to the dungeon and get nothing in drops and you're limited to only doing 5 dungeon floors at a time and these can be done in 5 minutes.

I would certainly advise you to look through the wiki when you buy the game since honestly they don't give you much information in the game for tutorials and I didn't even hear about things like 'exp-chaining' until I looked through the wiki. It makes the games a lot easier.

Pretty much if you're playing the game on the first play through I would just advise you to grind out as much money as possible and ignore trying to make friends with the characters since it seems pretty hard to do if you're unexperienced.

I would still recommend the game for a fun little time if you can look past these small annoyances."

reviewText:
I love this game. It starts simple and easy but the more you progress the more difficult it becomes and if you like truly finishing your games this can sink a whole monkey ton of time as well as getting to be difficult enough that you feel like your playing a bullet hell type of game.

Your a bankrupt little girl who gets some help from a fairy and to pay off your huge debt you set up an item shop. It has a lot of humor in it and a lovable main character.

Most people stop there I notice. But there is so much more after you pay your debt. Even I haven't completed the dungeon yet... I don't have the skills to get that far but I can say that the monsters start off with you one shotting them and them moving at a snails pace to hit you. At some point it turns into an enemy that can shoot lasers in all directions and can warp around the map that takes 1000 hits before they die. Then you realize you ♥♥♥♥♥♥ it off when it comes back to life... only angrier this time.

Good times.

You also have the freedom to customize the way your shop looks, which is always fun.

reviewText:
Bro, it's a game where you run the item shop in a JRPG, and you get a nice little dungeon side game. You run around a multi-floor dungeon, battling enemies with Zelda ALttP-Style controls, opening chests for loot, and selling everything you get from the dungeons in your shop. Customers get quite annoying and the tutorials are extremely lengthy, but it's nothing you can't tolerate.
The gameplay might not be everyone's cup of tea, so you might want to try this game out via some- other, more swashbuckling means- before you buy it.

reviewText: Capitalism, Ho!
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Racketeer - The game where you rip off small children and the elderly for fame and fortune! Capitalism ho!

Seriously, you play a shopkeeper of a stereotypical RPG, catering to both the regular townsfolk, as well as the occasional adventurer.

Oddly enough, the game actually has surprisingly good writing, with a unique and interesting assortment of eccentric characters set to a rather ridiculous plotline which works not just in spite of, but specifically because of how silly it is.

A lot of various addictive qualities show up in Recettear, such as RPG-style leveling of your character/shop, an economy where you purchase materials and have to buy low/sell high, as well as witty and charming dialogue.

You'll find a modest variety of characters enter your store; a small girl, an elderly man, a housewife and a generic common man for the regular townsfolk, each with their own personal buying habits. Toss in the more unique characters such as your brattish rival with a cynical faery of her own, a runaway princess-turned drunken assassin, a cyborg who is kind of new to the concept of money"
hoursPlayed: and you'll find yourself entertained for quite long periods at a time interacting with them.\n\nHaggling is an artform
voteText: and you get significantly rewarded for giving an offer that will be accepted on the first try rather than just going back and forth until someone either gives in or they meet in the middle. As such
helpfulPercent: there's actually some pretty shrewd tactics to manage when trying to haggle with customers
votesHelpful: and learning their personal traits and spending habits can be quite beneficial.\n\nAs a whole
votesTotal: it's a fairly unique game. There have been others vaguely similar to it before
votesFunny:
where you buy low and sell high... but none which have have nearly as much polish and just sheer charm to the personalities you interact with in Recettear.



Final Verdict:

It's really quite enjoyable for what it is. If you like shopping
commentsCount: or even just anything similar to facebook or flash games
column16: you'll probably adore Recettear. It's value for retaining a player's interest can be a bit less than ideal
column18: as there is an "end" to the game. There are some nice options for increasing replay value
column19: but you'll probably only find yourself doing one or two playthroughs every few years. It's a nice game to come back to once in awhile
column20:
but not on a consistent basis.


Overall Score: About 80%. It's really probably the best game of it's kind out there
column21: and the writing is great! The content duration's a bit short
column23: and considering the game type... you might want to wait for it to go on sale; $20 is a little bit much. $15 is reasonable

reviewText:
Truly unique and excellent gaming experience.

Recettear places you in charge of an item shop where you supply adventurers and other random NPC's. The shop management elements (from pricing to inventory to layout) are well thought out. But in addition to that there is the adventure. You can explore various dungeons along to find out a long forgotten secret as well as have fun with the various adventurers you have been equipping.

The dungeon gameplay is simple action-RPG fare, but again very well balanced and a lot of fun. It is also one of the main sources of rarer commodities that you will be selling in your store.

What might seem like a quick bit of casual fun will end up being a day long obsession. This game is highly addictive. :)

reviewText:
This game too me a while to really master as I'm certainly not the best with my savings. However, what really helps is that when you are unable to pay a debt and have to start over, you get to keep your merchant level, adventures keep their levels, you keep the upgrades to the shop AND you get to keep all the items you didn't manage to sell, giving you the ability to bounceback much more!

Not to mention the fusion ability is really helpful to gain some really expensive and unique items to sell to more effectively pay off that bill.

The characters are a lot of fun with many interesting stories too going on around the place with many different and interesting mechanics going on too.  This is  alittle hidden gem that requires a lot more attention and I really love it! Capitalism, Ho!

reviewText:
From the screens, I had assumed this game would have a fair amount of dungeon-crawly, character-leveling goodness, which, uh, isn't really the case. There's a fair amount of characters you gain access to send to the dungeon, but there isn't a huge reason to use any of them but the first guy since it's all pretty easy and pretty much the same.

I beat the game in 8 hours, spending most of my time focused on the shop - which, I get it, is the point of a game called Item Shop. But it felt like the game wanted to be more than just a shop sim, and it could have done a better job focusing on either the shop or the dungeon element.

It got eight hours out of me, but I ended up kinda ♥♥♥♥♥♥ that I gave it that at the end since there wasn't a whole lot of 'wrap-up' done with the numerous NPCs. I just kinda met the money goal and then that was it. Meh. Not for me.

reviewText:
I'd recommend this game to teenagers and under. I think that adults would get bored of this game within a few hours.

You play a girl who has to pay off her father's bank loan, by working in a store ( buy low, sell high ) and dungeon crawling for items, to sell in the store. The retail aspect is as uninteresting as working in a real life, retail store. The dungeon crawling is a basic hack 'n slash and reminded me of Zelda ( without the puzzles ) this aspect is fairly fun.

I paid $5 for this on sale, which is OK. I'd rather have paid $2.50 for it though. Definitely not worth any higher than $5.

reviewText: Conceptually very interesting, i won't deny they did a good job at making a management game revolving around JRPG characters in a JRPG world. Traditional to JRPG the story is going to be the most interesting part fo the game, unfortunately i'm downvoting because i found the game grindy and boring.\nI was constantly checking the marketplace only to be bored with zero encounters. The writing is silly cheesy fun, but can take forever and get on the nerves. The dungeons were painfully boring, dunno why they tried to shove an RPG into a perfectly good management game. Especially since the management itself isn't amazing, i feel like the game had a lot of interesting ways to innovate and explore. Instead EasyGameStation innovated a tiny bit, then all the dev power was put into the long dungeons enemies and loot art.\nI didn't come to reccettear wanting to play the dungeon crawly RPG elements, but i can tell that's where all the effort went, and it's the most boring part of the game. Though managing the shop is interesting and complicated I'd like a shop management sim with more refined features.

reviewText: I'm not sure what the appeal for this game is. I was looking forward to it so much after hearing all the hype and came away from it very dissatisfied with two half-baked systems that failed to engage me. The shopkeeping is fairly basic aside from a (simple but very fun, thought it was one of the best parts of the game) random price raising/decreasing. The combat is laughably simple.\n\nIn addition, if you fail to meet your debt, you have to repeat the entire game. While normally I like the idea of devestating failstates in a game (really enjoying XCOM, for instance), I didn't really want to sludge through another bunch of hours of this crap. In addition, it feels like the game was designed for the player to fail once- unless you can beat the game on your first try, the only benefit that doing well on your first runthrough is that you end up wasting more time playing this game. The second try is almost trivial since you keep you entire inventory after the first failure.

reviewText: A sweet little game on the facade, but pretty much unplayable without a spreadsheet open. By the time I had finished the game, I completely gave up on the RPG aspects and I had the numbers on the spreadsheet memorised. I also had a notebook open listing all the orders and the days on which to stock up items in my shop ... Essentially I was running an actual business. There's a few things to love and I genuinely enjoyed my experience, but when it comes right down to it, it's just not very fun for most people. Maybe if the spreadsheet was in-game and there wasn't a random NPC that breaks all your combos and you had more incentive to do the (surprisingly well-made) dungeon crawling, it'd be a great game, but as it stands now, it's just for the type to optimise numbers and people who love CAPITALISM (HO)!

reviewText:
When i first tried the demo for this game i thought to myself i can really get into this so i picked it up during a sale happy with my purchase. However after putting in a few hours with this game there is a fundamental issue with the mechanics that ruin this game for me and force me to not recommend it.

Now although its fun setting up your shop and adventuring in the dungeon for items to sell the game neglects to mention a major mechanic in the game that can actually make the game unplayable at times. The tutorial simply tells you that what you wanna do is buy items from people at 50% and sell for 130%. Fair enough and pretty straight forward. After a while however i started to notice that 130% was out of the question and even 120% would drive customers away. I would lower and lower the prices and still drive customers away at 90% and even 80% of the base cost. BUT THE TUTORIAL TOLD ME 130% WAS THE MAGIC NUMBER! I took to the internet to see what i was missing and what i discovered was the game fails to mention there are two invisible stats that drastically effect gameplay. Customer loyalty level and customer budget. Customers would come in trying to buy items they didnt even have the budget for no matter what price i set them at and then would leave mad which lowered their loyalty and budget even more. By week three the game was unplayable.

Now i could probably easily start over fresh with new found information about how the budget and loyalty stats work but do i really wanna have to take notes while i play. keeping track of invisible stats the game never mentioned to me to make sure i didnt try to sell items my customers will never even be able to afford. Invisible stats ruine this game for me.

reviewText:
Gomenasai, my name is Ken-Sama.
I’m a 27 year old American Otaku (Anime fan for you gaijins). I draw Anime and Manga on my tablet, and spend my days perfecting my art and playing superior Japanese games. (Disgaea, Final Fantasy, Persona series)
I train with my Katana every day, this superior weapon can cut clean through steel because it is folded over a thousand times, and is vastly superior to any other weapon on earth. I earned my sword license two years ago, and I have been getting better every day.
I speak Japanese fluently, both Kanji and the Osaka dialect, and I write fluently as well. I know everything about Japanese history and their bushido code, which I follow 100%
When I get my Japanese visa, I am moving to Tokyo to attend a prestigious High School to learn more about their magnificent culture. I hope I can become an animator for Studio Ghibli or a game designer!
I own several kimonos, which I wear around town. I want to get used to wearing them before I move to Japan, so I can fit in easier. I bow to my elders and seniors and speak Japanese as often as I can, but rarely does anyone manage to respond.

reviewText:
I had really been looking forward to this game... but after completing it, I'm sorry to say that I cannot recommend Recettear. You expect there to be more when really the game is pretty shallow.

The Ragnarok Online-ish graphics got me hooked at the start and I liked the no-nonsense dungeon crawling and the shop aspect.. but there's just not enough here to keep you engaged. Or if there is, the game is not organized in such a way that you can enjoy it without a guide.

First of all, the dungeon crawling gets really repetitive. Fighting doesn't require you to be clever, because you're OP all of the time. After you unlock your fourth and final skill on a character.. you switch to a new one because they just get stale.
Worse, dungeon crawling is actually detrimental to your progress, because you rarely find items worth the hassle, but you lose 2 units of ingame time that you could have spent selling stuff in your shop.

The shop system's got a tutorial that makes you haggle with your customers, although suggesting a price they'll like is the only way to get combo bonuses for selling, which are more useful than the extra buck from high sales prices.

I also found it very, very difficult to survive the debt cycle (someone in the comments even asked So did anyone survive the first round?"). When you can't pay back your debt on time
recommended: but you start again from the beginning
hoursPlayed: only you keep the items you have in stock and your merchant level (that gives you access to more stuff on the market + other stuff that helps). The second time around is too easy. I finished the last ingame week doing nothing but killing time and still had 1 million pix when I payed off the final debt of 500k. This should be more balanced.\n\nThe crafting system is a nice addition
voteText: but suffers from a lack of menu integration. You literally have to write stuff down you want to hunt for in the dungeons. Would have been much nicer to be able to pull up a menu and see "Aha. I need 2 more pieces of X to make Y." That's why I ended up using it just to make stuff I had randomly collected the ingredients for. It's very inconvenient.\nSure
helpfulPercent: I could have played it smarter and looked into a guide to make lots more money by crafting. But honestly? When hunting for the items isn't fun.. why would anyone bother?\n\nAll in all
votesHelpful: I don't really want to drop a huge pile of dung on this game. It has its enjoyable aspects
votesTotal: but as it is
votesFunny: I just don't think it'll be fun for you. That's why I'm not recommending it. If you like
commentsCount: you can play the demo. But don't expect much more than the content you see there."

reviewText: NO SPOILERS\n\nI don't understand how this game got such overwhelming positive reviews. The game mechanics are horrible, trash infact. The game developers had a great idea or concept for a item shop game but the systems and implementations are utter garbage. The story made me genuinely laugh out loud at times, but I would have rather watched the story unfold like an anime tv show then play this game, in fact I ended up going to youtube just to see how it ends. Without going into details, the story is your usual young-teen-hero-anime show story with some fourth-wall breaking stuff about video games. However, the story is not good enough for me to want to continue to play the game just for it. The mechanics are so clunky, repetitive, and downright head scratching it makes me wonder why I bothered to put in 12 hours. I think I did only because of the overwhelming positive numbers making believe that this must be one of the best games ever...however it is far from even being an average title and I do not recommend this game at all.

reviewText:
+
• Love the Japanese art style, in general.
• Very interesting combination of dungeons and selling items at the same time.
• Different characters and classes, with nice dialogue.
• Every adventurer plays differently, with a variety of special attacks.
• It's fun to make profit and kill stuff, no doubt about that.

-
• Disappointing dungeons, monsters randomly thrown together.
• Dungeons rarely have anything really valuable in them - it's more for grinding out certain items out of monsters in order to fuse it to a better item.
• Art style of the monsters is pretty bad, too bad that they didn't bother making them the same way as the main characters.
• Too short of a game, in my opinion - you have around 30 days until the deadline, after that your job is done and what is left would be further unlocking, + mode or survival".
• Your customers have no sense of logic or integrity. Every kind of customer buys pretty much anything

reviewText: I normally really like shopkeeper games but this is not much more than a visual novel. Adventuring is a repetitive hack-n-slash, though I enjoyed the bosses. Selling things is also repetitive: you haggle the price up a bit and that's all there is to it. Those are the only gameplay elements. The rest is going to locations in town to trigger dialogue with NPCs. There's no managing costs, hiring workers, or anything else you'd expect from running an item store.

reviewText:
Before I start, I actually have about 6+ extra hours on it already, having played this game previously on my girlfriend's computer, so my current time on time spent playing this game isn't exactly accurate.

I have to say I love this game personally. It's cute, fun, and addictive. It's probably my favorite that I have in my steam library right now. That being said, this is one of those situations where I wish steam had a meh" button instead of simply recommending or not recommending a game.

So here's the way the game works. (only game mechanics
date: no story-spoilers) The item shop gameplay is pretty simple. Buy low
hoursPlayed: try to make enough to pay off your debt each week. You're restricted on the amount of actions you can do each day. This whole part of the game plays like one of those in-browser flash games. That isn't exactly a bad thing as a whole. The art style is pleasing to look at enough to keep you playing and the game still feels rewarding when you actually figure out how it works. As the game adds more and more to the way the game works

reviewText: The game is fine but beware: Carpe Fulgur, the translation team behind this game, has been known to make unnecessary changes and edits to the games they translate much like Commie Subs or 4kidz used to do. They do this because the game conflicts with their sensibilities or their particular world view so I would not recommend you support these devs as they censor the games and stray from the source material especially when dialog or scenarios conflict with their extreme-progressive ideologies.\n\nJust something to consider about the quality of the English version’s writing that is important and I didn’t see mentioned before.

reviewText:
The game does present itself correctly...you run an item shop.
I suppose when I saw the game and some of the features it looked like it had Action-RPG elements that seemed more fulfilling than I thought it would be, so after playing for a while the game took a disappointing turn quickly.

You play a very rudimentary High/Low bartering game that gets choresome and repetitive quickly, and occasionally delve into a dungeon" for a few floors taking control of a hired mercenary with a primitive top-down action system...whose game you'd rather be playing if it weren't for uninspired dungeon floors
date: poor collision hit boxes and the slow grind for random item drops as you look for each floor's exit.\n\nThere's very little sense of direct advancement
recommended: and a desperate disconnect between the gameplay modes with a very shallow playspace in each that leaves you feeling like you are stuck between a watered down simulation game and a watered down secret of mana with no will
hoursPlayed: motivation or desire to continue in each.\n\nThe art

reviewText:
Based on good reviews in PC Gamer, I bought Recettear: An Item Shop's Tale on sale and gave it a go. Although I am charmed by the idea of an RPG from the perspective of the shopkeepers in town, I find this game to be a poor experience.

Managing your shop is awkward and tedious. Walking about town to get stuff for your shop is tedious and artificially slow. Bartering with your shop customers is a repetitive exercise. Adventuring in the dungeon to get stuff for your shop features laughable, simplistic gameplay mechanics.

And the cutscenes... oh the cutscenes. They go on forever, padded with juvenile humor. You can't mash the button fast enough to get through them.

I really wanted, and expected, to like Recettear more than I do, but I'm just not feeling it. I suggest finding a gameplay video before purchasing Recettear.

reviewText: Recettear: An Item Shop's Tale is probably the cutest worst game there is. Ill-conceived better covers it: you play half the game as a top-down dungeon crawler and the other half as manager to the eponymous item shop, with neither halves being properly implemented in the first place. I get the feeling that the developers, EasyGameStation, had very ambitious ideas for the concept of Item Merchant Game" except that they've botched everything until what they made barely resembles a game anymore! I'll explain...\n\nYou are Recette
date: spunky little girl entrepreneur required by the faerie bond collection agency to raise enough money to repay her father's exorbitant adventuring debt. For this task you have your house located smack dab in the middle of RPG City
recommended: which you've converted into an Item Shop for the convenience of all. Sell items to the roaming adventurers
voteText: repay your debt; simple enough

votesTotal: she is flat out LYING to you. This is far above what many villagers can afford and will not increase important customer loyalty. This is especially villainous considering there is no other way than trial-and-error to determine a customer's comfort range.\n\nThe process of selling and bargaining for optimal profits and customer loyalty is stupid and punishes experimentation. Any experimentation in bargaining reduces important customer loyalty which reduces the overall money pool they're willing to invest in your products. Worse

reviewText:
Receattear has you play as a young chick fending for herself with a massive debt to pay off.

And no, she doesn't pay it off that way. She runs a local store!

This game is super fun and *incredibly* addictive. When I started playing this, when I was off work ill, I played it non-stop, and actually dreamed about it for a bit. It gets into your brain.

The mechanics, however, are quite repeatative, and the process of acquiring items for your store is very tedious. The story, though, is charming and enjoyable (if you like JRPG sorts of games, you will appreciate it).

My main criticism is that after 10 hours of play, I failed the game at the last hurdle, after being asked to complete *an impossible challenge* (I think it is anyway). The only way I can deduce to complete the game is to play it *twice*, and fail the first time. You prepare tonnes of items in the first play, really good stuff, and sell large the second run through.

This, to me, is incredibly annoying game design, and is the reason I have not completed, as I refuse to put myself through another playthrough. For this reason, I'd avoid it, but if you can put up with that, then go ahead!

Nilesy
